subject: Medicine
title: The Neuron: Brain's Building Block
description: A 60-second lesson on The Neuron: Brain's Building Block.

hook.text: A single neuron fires up to 200 times per second. Multiply that by 86 billion and you get consciousness.

buildup.text: Neurons are specialized cells with a body, dendrites that receive signals, and an axon that sends them.

discovery.text: Electrical impulses travel down the axon, then trigger chemical signals that jump to the next neuron.

twist.text: Neurons don't actually touch each other. There's a tiny gap called a synapse where chemistry takes over.

climax.text: This combination of electricity and chemistry creates the fastest signaling system in your body.

punchline.text: Your thoughts are sparks jumping across tiny gaps.

quiz.question: How do signals pass between neurons?
options: Chemical signals jump across a tiny gap called a synapse
Electrical current flows directly between touching neurons
Sound waves vibrate between neuron surfaces
